26.9 Advice to your former self

So you were caught by the tail end of that a little bit. But if you could go back the first year, what would you tell your former self in order to to get the most out of your time at university? I mean I think you did a pretty good job while you were here and you made the most of lots of opportunities going and getting placements and internships. But what would you what would you tell your former self now that you‚Äôre older and wiser?

Jonathan: Interesting. So with stress and an effort that university takes, I think it‚Äôs it‚Äôs really important to be to be looking after your mental health. And that goes for, for looking for, for units, to take for, making sure that your, your workload is balanced. And I think at the University of Manchester you a great job in sort of saying these units, in particular are going to be very difficult, very challenging, you‚Äôre gonna want to try and balance them out, so you definitely shouldn‚Äôt feel bad going, I‚Äôve heard from students, maybe that this unit in particular, is a little bit easier. This is gonna help help make things sane for me at university. So, I mean, first year I did a computer science in math and end up dropping the maths

Right: Okay

Jonathan: I love it but I think it‚Äôs described to me at the time. I absolutely agree it‚Äôs 60% Computer science and 60% maths, so its a lot of work. And yeah, making sure that what you‚Äôve got on your plate is something you can handle and at the end of the day, something you‚Äôre enjoying is really important.

Yeah, yeah. And that‚Äôs that, you know, looking looking back now.

Sort of I think, I mean, I see a lot of students working really hard, which is good but I think it‚Äôs sometimes it can be a little bit unhealthy. When, I‚Äôve done it myself as well, you just work too hard, you just burn out and then things go wrong. It‚Äôs counterproductive in the longer term anyway.

Jonathan: Yeah, at the end of the day you can make opportunities. You will find opportunities, that can happen. Even if you struggle university or it‚Äôs not quite working. But there isn‚Äôt another you. That‚Äôs really important thing to get, and that‚Äôs, you really need to do whatever. It takes, whatever you can to look after yourself, physically and mentally. It‚Äôs so important.

Good Well, thanks for joining us Jonathan. Thanks for coming and sharing your story. It‚Äôs good to hear about how you got to where you are now and look forward to hearing about what you get up to in the future.

Jonathan: Yeah, thank you so much for having me.

27 Alice‚Äôs story

Meet Alexandra (Alice) PƒÉcuraru, see figure @ref(fig:alice-fig) she graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Computer Science with Business and Management and Industrial Experience in 2022 when this episode was first recorded. Alice worked at home.barclays, morganstanley.com and thg.com before moving to publicissapient.com in London.

(#fig:alice-fig)(ref:captionalice)

(ref:captionalice) Alice PƒÉcuraru. Picture reused from linkedin.com/in/alexandra-pacuraru with permission, thanks Alice.

(ref:podcastblurb)

27.1 What‚Äôs your story Alice?

So, welcome Alice, thank you for coming on the show. So, it‚Äôd be good to hear more about your journey from student professional. You‚Äôve been here for four years and lots happened in four years. You‚Äôve done a lot of things. A lot of things have happened in the world in the last four years, you‚Äôve had your graduation yesterday. Yeah, which was very cool. And so can you tell us a little bit more about what? Let‚Äôs start with, what‚Äôs your name and where‚Äôd you come from?

Alice: Yes. So, hi thank you for having me. My name is actually Alexandra but I go by Alice, to not confuse people. .

How do I say your surname because I‚Äôve struggled with your surname.

So it depends. So in the Romanian you have a little hat (Breve) on top of the a, which is pronounced ƒÉ. But the thing is, when I fill in forms or anything here, obviously I can‚Äôt put the hat on so the British version I think would be PacoRaru right okay the correct version in my opinion is Puckurado okay but it depends how you roll your R‚Äôs, there‚Äôs a bunch of things involved in it. So it go, I go by anything. When I when I hear Pac I‚Äôm like okay it‚Äôs me

You‚Äôre from Romania.

Alice: Yeah really.

So my Romanian geography‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs kind of a circle-ish?

Alice: A fish. Oh it looks like a fish in my opinion. (See figure @ref(fig:romania-fig))

(#fig:romania-fig)(ref:captionromania)

(ref:captionromania) Romania, shown in dark green here, is a country which borders borders Bulgaria to the south, Ukraine to the north, Hungary to the west, Serbia to the southwest, Moldova to the east, and the Black Sea to the southeast. It is shaped like a fish, with its tail touching the Black Sea. Creative Commons BY-SA map of Romania by NuclearVacuum via Wikimedia Commons w.wiki/6t8B adapted using the Wikipedia App üá∑üá¥

You‚Äôve got the Black Sea? You‚Äôve got Bucharest in the South. Are you from Bucharest or somewhere else?

Alice: Yeah. Just Bucharest is quite easy. I feel like your Romanian geography is really good because I‚Äôve been asked if it‚Äôs a village in the UK before.

What, if Bucharest is a village?!

Alice: No, if Romania is a village in the UK and I was like, Not really, but sure, okay good.

27.2 Why study Computer Science?

So can you say a little bit about what made you choose to study computer science as a thing to study for four years?

Alice: Yeah, so I‚Äôll begin by announcing that I finished computer science with business and management and I feel the reason behind it is because I was very unsure what I wanted to study, I really liked organising, little events for my high school so I was thinking maybe business or management might be cool but then I joined the robotics club in my high school and then I was like, well, computer science, quite cool but maybe not on its own because it was an all more or less a boys club and it was robotics. So it‚Äôs a lot more hardware than I personally like and then and then I was thinking maybe I should do something completely different. I don‚Äôt know why. I have a theory that everyone at one point wants to do criminology. I‚Äôm not sure exactly what happens maybe, just because it sounds really cool. But I wanted to do that as well. And then, in the end, I decided that I want to study something that I feel is challenging for three years. Just because I had a fear of getting bored of my degree because it‚Äôs three years. It‚Äôs a lot of doing just one degree. So then I was like, you know what? I‚Äôm just gonna do computer science, seems a very challenging so for me, at least, so I‚Äôm gonna have a lot of fun and also do it with business and management just because University of Manchester, obviously, they stopped doing the course, but it was out the point where I applied one of the only, I think four or five unis ‚Ä¶

Okay, that‚Äôs interesting.

That offered the course, right?

So had you studied computer science formally at school? Or was it something on the edges? Like you say like there was a club or something where people did stuff?

Alice: We did study formally as well, you got to pick in high school, which part of high school, you want to do, if you want to do humanities or Sciences and in sciences, you can choose between life sciences and computer science and maths, and I just picked a computer science and maths, which is called Informatics in Romania, which is basically computer science. We did a little bit of coding in C++ by a little bit. I mean we were coding algorithms, but when we would ask anything further than that, it would be quite difficult for us to comprehend what was happening. Why we need class names, etc, etc.

So that‚Äôs quite a heavy (difficult) language to start with?

Alice: Yeah, we‚Äôre also doing it on paper. We did have a Informatics lab in our, and we kind of knew how to use I think we‚Äôre using code blocks, to run code, but day-to-day, just because we‚Äôre so many students, we couldn‚Äôt all fit in that lab. So we‚Äôre just coding on paper. So I feel like that‚Äôs even more difficult because then you write on paper and then the teacher needs to be like yeah. That‚Äôs not right. Checking your syntax. Yeah you can‚Äôt run in be like why the teacher needs to tell you but I think it‚Äôs really good for debugging now because then when I came to uni and then we‚Äôre doing Java, the lecturer asked us to code on paper before I never was so outraged. I was like oh this is like school. So I think it‚Äôs good. Maybe

I think maybe it develops skills in code reading (Spinellis 2003) perhaps in that you‚Äôre not computer science often focuses on writing code and that‚Äôs a skill you need to learn but actually reading other people‚Äôs code. Maybe doing it on paper helps you?

Alice: Yeah, it does help because

You think a bit more carefully about what you‚Äôre doing. You‚Äôre not just well let‚Äôs try that and see if it works.

Alice: Exactly. And it‚Äôs also, you know, when you write an algorithm and you need to check it against test cases, like in a (coding) interview, for example, it‚Äôs so it‚Äôs not about the idea they need to check. It‚Äôs about, where do you put on the paper, the variables. And then remember how they update, like, kind of having a little framework for that, that really helped me. So, yeah, that‚Äôs how I ended up in computer science.

Good. Okay. So, how did when you got here? How did it meet with your expectations? Was it like, okay, this is kind of what I was expecting or were there any sort of surprises where you thought? Well, this is a bit different to what I was expecting?

Alice: Well, I‚Äôd like to add the fact that I‚Äôve never been in Manchester before coming here, for my freshers week. So expectation‚Ä¶ Don‚Äôt know

Or the UK, I guess.

Alice: Oh, I went to London once. Does that count? I don‚Äôt know. Maybe,

That‚Äôs the UK!

Alice: Yeah, it was a holiday it was quite fun but then I came to Manchester. Everything was new to I got here a day late because I thought freshers means a week of parties, right? So I was like, oh it‚Äôs fine. I found a better flight for Tuesday so I was like, surely no one‚Äôs gonna miss me for one day? I actually missed the first lecture and my first lab. So I had to join a different lab. Okay, so I was there, I think I was in (room) LF31. And we got the little booklet with the Raspberry Pi‚Äôs. And I didn‚Äôt have a data because the data was bad and then in LF31, I didn‚Äôt know how to connect the Wi-Fi and I had to follow this little booklet and I didn‚Äôt know what a Raspberry Pi was but I was too afraid to google it because people would see my screen, it was very funny. So that was traumatic

Not a great start?

Alice: Yeah. What is funny is that I was talking to all of my other friends that weren‚Äôt really doing hardware before uni, and all of them found the same. So it‚Äôs quite funny now to kind of see how far we‚Äôve come. So I feel like it‚Äôs also nice because now if someone that talks to a computer scientist, they expect them to know EVERYTHING. So that I‚Äôm so sorry. I don‚Äôt know how a computer works. I‚Äôm like, I don‚Äôt know either it‚Äôs fine!

Um, well, you you DO know more about it than you did four years ago?

Alice: Yeah, no, obviously I do know that, but it was quite funny. So in terms of the first day, a very intense, but then I feel like it‚Äôs good because then I had to ask questions. So I just had to be like, you know, Alice. Let‚Äôs put the ego aside, and let‚Äôs just go somewhere and beg someone to explain to me what‚Äôs happening. But in terms of the first year, I really liked it. I thought I had obviously a little bit of an advantage just because I did coding a little bit before. So, I think that was very helpful for me in the idea that it was a bit less overwhelming. I mean, obviously other friends that I know that they didn‚Äôt do any coding before I think Carmen mentioned it that she never did coding before coming to uni, so I‚Äôm pretty sure they handled it well, as well. I just feel like for me, it was a bit easier, just because I got time to kind of be like, at least I could show them how bubble sort works and maybe they‚Äôll leave me for a bit. So I found it really nice. Expectations, I didn‚Äôt have any, but I really enjoyed it but also again doing computer science with business meant that I wasn‚Äôt doing any of the hardware courses

Right.

Alice: Which I feel like my have been a bit more overwhelming for me just because I have no experience in hardware. But it was really nice. I loved the first year team project

So fast forwarding to well. So what did you do in your first year team project? What you did you build? Can you remember? So yeah, time ago now.

Alice: Oh my god. I remember it clearly. It was called unicycle and it was this app. I think someone was telling me everyone does that. Like there‚Äôs at least one team that does it. I think they were two teams and I, yeah, that did it. But we incorporated more parts of things that we felt like uni students need. Which obviously one of them was having a list of ingredients and spitting out the recipes. That‚Äôs the go-to for everyone. Yeah, I think we had another bit, which was a Google Calendar integration. Um, so you can see your classes where they are at deadlines. And then the other one was a Yelp API.

Right.

Alice: Where you could see the closest clubs around you, but we kind of connected all of them. So, for example, if you‚Äôre looking for club on Friday evening and you had a deadline on Monday, it wouldn‚Äôt let you because you have a deadline Monday. It was quite fun. It was really low level and but we had so much fun doing it.

And it worked then because sometimes first year team projects go BANG, not because of technology because of politics. Just luck of the draw, which team you‚Äôre in. So your team worked well?

Alice: Yeah, I mean, I don‚Äôt think we were best friends, but we didn‚Äôt hate each other. That we were just kind of there. Like, let‚Äôs figure out. Let‚Äôs figure something out. And you, we won something as well, which is so funny. We want the most world improving idea with the recipe bit. I was like, we definitely sold it really well. Right? Because we were out there giving our body and soul to the judges, telling them how amazing and innovative idea is. So it worked out in the end. We had a lot of fun.

27.3 Second year

Good so fast forward to second year. So this is things started happening and you were applying for placement, had you decided before that you were going to do a placement or was it something? Because some people decide at the beginning the second year, like, oh, that‚Äôs a good idea, let‚Äôs do that. Had you decided before you came or so you‚Äôd already. You knew that you wanted to do a placement right from the beginning?

Alice: Yeah, for me was actually one of the reasons why I wanted University of Manchester just because obviously I wanted to go abroad which is on its own a big cost for anyone coming from. Especially I feel like a country where people are less (wealthy?) than the country they are going in. So for example, from Romania to the UK, so I was kind of like a little plan. I was pitching it to my parents and I was like you support me for two years from then on I‚Äôm on my own I‚Äôll do a little placement. I‚Äôll put money aside, I‚Äôll do my last two years of uni so that was the plan from the beginning and that‚Äôs why Manchester because also the people that I knew that graduated from Manchester did the same thing. They did the placement, they really liked it. So that was kind of my top choice, I think it played it big role of picking University of Manchester.

So where were you looking for jobs to do? What was your strategy did you have a strategy?

Alice: Don‚Äôt think, I‚Äôm not sure because I did the spring insights in first year. Yeah. Okay. So that would have helped.

So actually for people who don‚Äôt know, what is spring insight? (See section @ref(areuexperienced))

Alice: Oh yeah, people don‚Äôt know this stuff. True. Because that‚Äôs also that‚Äôs also another thing I found out from my PASS (Peer Assisted Study Scheme) leaders who were also my friends but they did one and they were you all need to apply because it‚Äôs so fun. It‚Äôs so important and everything. So I did the same in when I was a first year.

That was a JP Morgan, was it?

Alice: I was at Morgan Stanley and Barclays (see figure @ref(fig:barclays-tower-fig)). I did two of them.

(#fig:barclays-tower-fig)(ref:captionbarclays)

(ref:captionbarclays) Barclays is a British multinational universal bank, headquartered in Canary Wharf, London, England. CC-BY picture of Barclays offices at One Churchill Place in London by Matt Brown on Wikimedia Commons w.wiki/6qK9

That‚Äôs a week or two weeks, is it?

Alice: Yeah. Spring that means Easter break. So it kind of depends so it‚Äôs basically a week long or two week long mini internship, in which the company that you‚Äôre interning at just gives you a little bit of a taste of what is happening. They do a lot of really nice events for the interns. They explain what the company is doing. For banks obviously they have a lot of explaining to do because no one in computer science has a finance background. And in general I don‚Äôt think any 19 year old or first year student knows anything about banking anyway so they do a lot of explaining. They pay someone to shadow them salary as such

They pay like accommodation and expenses? I think so addition and they feed you, right?

Alice: and some companies do also pay you separately, which was really nice, you know, to kind of get my first money ever.

And then I think the thing about that is good is then you‚Äôve got a big name on your CV. So when you were applying for placements in your second year you had Barclays and Morgan Stanley, two big names on your CV. And say you know, even if you don‚Äôt go into banking, it‚Äôs like, well, I‚Äôve done this.

Alice: Exactly kind of shows that you took initiative and you applied and you had to interact with people like this and you also got it. So it‚Äôs kind of like, well, definitely. They did something right. Right. But I do feel, it‚Äôs kind of a small downside just because obviously the companies that do have the means to run week long internships for students are also the bigger banks.

So there is (only) a few tech companies.

Alice: Yeah.

So there‚Äôs not much diversity. I‚Äôm not gonna find a startup doing a spring insight?

Alice: Exactly. It‚Äôs mostly banks or consultancies, I think, right.

But they are valuable?

Alice: Yeah, the important thing is the experience and to see how it feels just because, especially in computer science I feel like after you graduate you realise that the way that so many avenues in which we can go to but now it‚Äôs even more growing than banking and the financial bit. So I think it‚Äôs quite nice from the beginning to kind of, try out to see how it is. I personally, I do think spring insights are really important. I suggested to everyone to apply just because it‚Äôs kind of like not that many people apply obviously because you know first semester you and you don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happening. Why I apply for internships? But there were so useful ‚Ä¶

And relatively, I mean not easy, but easier if you‚Äôre applying for an internship or a permanent job, the interview might be a bit more involved. Alice: Yeah, it is very much also behavioural (interview) heavy (see section @ref(hrinterview)) and I feel like it really helped me because ..

What do you mean by behavioural interviews, right? So they‚Äôre asking you questions and trying to find out about your personality.

Alice: Yeah, and I feel like that helped me so much when I was looking to my friends that were obviously applying for placements, or after for grad jobs, They‚Äôre kind of talking like, oh, I don‚Äôt even know how to prepare for a behavioural interview, right? Because you get to second yoorur third year where you know the hard really hard bits will be the technical and you kind of like think behavioural like oh, it‚Äôs fine. I‚Äôll just talk to them right? And because obviously, in first year, I was so panicked because I was like oh my god this is my first interview ever. I did all the prep, I would be like reading their Twitter to find cool things I can talk to them about. Reading their values, finding things that I did that match with their values. I kind of buzzword that their values

Alice: it makes sense because front-end technology changes so much and it‚Äôs so dependant on the language that we use, Whereas obviously, I didn‚Äôt use, I didn‚Äôt use the backend that I did in software engineering is just the algorithms were there. So I could remember like a little sorting function that I could put in and that worked regardless of the language or the framework that we used.

And I guess, I mean, would you say that front end stuff is relatively easy to pick up or not? I mean, if you like if you‚Äôve not done any react but you know a little bit of I know basic HTML and CSS, for example. How easy is it to pick up React?

Alice: I think, I think it‚Äôs easy to pick up. I just think it‚Äôs hard to DO. You can get into it quickly but then I would quickly realise how bad my code from the beginning was. You pick it up and if you don‚Äôt do it properly, you‚Äôre probably not going to be that good at it and you‚Äôre not gonna be able to do that many things with it. But obviously it‚Äôs easy to pick up in the sense that you can do something simple quite quickly. Yeah so that that‚Äôs always nice. Obviously in back end you need you can‚Äôt really do something easy or maybe yeah you can make it more efficient etc but you soon need a LOT of knowledge to even get the first part.

Okay good. So, we‚Äôve talked about this a little bit but the were there are many other obstacles that you faced in finding employment? I think we talked about most of them. Were there any anything else that we haven‚Äôt mentioned about your struggle to find a job?

27.5 Job struggles

Alice: I feel like the main struggle was to find a job that matched what I needed from a placement. I‚Äôve liked a lot easier to find companies that you like that do grad schemes, just because in the worst case scenario just apply for an entry level job, whereas having a placement, there‚Äôs so many types of placements, right? There is the three-month placement. Six months placement finding one company was quite limiting choices. So that kind of raised the bar with the interviews and it was a bit more stress involved, but I think the main one was just kind of juggling everything and preparing for interviews. There were kind of the first technical interviews I‚Äôve done as well so it was that.

So we‚Äôve got a couple of things here. what were the main things you learnt, would you say what the main things you learned from doing your year in industry.

Alice: I‚Äôve decided, because I was talking to this with a lot of people that did placement in general, I think the main thing that I learnt was to be more confident. Confident in the sense not necessarily to speak in a meeting. Although obviously that‚Äôs also really helpful. confident in the way that when someone comes with an issue, I don‚Äôt panic. If I don‚Äôt know it straight away it‚Äôs kind of like someone tells me oh can you do this by as soon as possible and then I‚Äôm not like, oh my god, I don‚Äôt know this language, I don‚Äôt know what this word means. I‚Äôve never heard of it in my life. It‚Äôs kind of like always fine. I‚Äôll figure out, I‚Äôll google it. I‚Äôll ask someone, it‚Äôs kind of like having so many moments, which you don‚Äôt know what is happening and having to force yourself to learn about it and to google it and then you somehow finish it right. I think it‚Äôs really useful because in uni, when this happens, which is also roughly at the beginning of every single course, and module, you still get a little bit of guidance. So you‚Äôre expected to know some things from before. I feel like when people give you a job, something they‚Äôre not necessarily like oh you should know this. It‚Äôs kind of like, can you please figure out and do something for me? So I feel like confidence came to it and it also applied to a lot of things, right? Like if someone would ask me to help them with an interview or to finish a project or to apply to a company or whatever it was kind of like I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happening, but I‚Äôll figure out in the end.

27.6 Final year project: Coding their Future

So let‚Äôs move on to final year a project. So you‚Äôve done your placement, you‚Äôve come back to university and things were returning to normal at this point so you‚Äôve done the entirety of your placement online?

Alice: Yeah. Except the end right.

Okay, so you did finally get to actually meet the people that you were working and that must have been good, I guess, but kind of at the same time a little bit crazy

Alice: it was kind of really weird just because I got used to staying in the house and having snacks all the time next to me. And then, if you like being after being one year at home and your own comfort, like if you want to just call someone or to clean your oven, in the middle of the day, you can just take 10 minutes and it‚Äôs done. However, then when I had in those Fridays to go to work, I was like what if I‚Äôm very thirsty? I kind of lost all social connection anyway, it was fine though. It was fun. Yeah, good.

So back to university things were returning to normal and what was your what was your final year project. Yeah for our listeners. Can you explain what you did?

Alice: My final year project was called Coding their Future and my tutor was you. And for my final year project, I basically helped and supported teaching computer science with a secondary school in Greater Manchester. So I feel like it‚Äôs quite open-ended which are quite liked and the idea that we could figure out what we wanted to do after talking to the teacher, who would be like providing them with an application that would help them or teaching literally every single week to the kids or doing a couple of one-off teaching sessions with the students. So it was really nice. It was really nice. In general, the aspect of being able to kind of use my third year project and actually help someone just because I obviously third year projects have really nice or some of the titles on that list when you have to select that are really flashy and sound really cool but in the end I was kind of like if I do have a year. I mean yeah a couple of months and I can do something I might as well kind of use what I know to just help someone and I‚Äôve like education is really rewarding in that sense because you can genuinely, it‚Äôs quite dramatic to say change someone‚Äôs. I‚Äôve probably I didn‚Äôt change anyone‚Äôs lives but it‚Äôs just like kind of help star. Some, you dance towards them which is something that is very dear to my heart especially for women in STEM.

So we should say the school is Fairfield high school for girls. Yes. In a state school in Droylsden Manchester and we need to, We need to acknowledge Mrs.¬†Roland, don‚Äôt we? Because Mrs, Rowland is amazing. She‚Äôs been that hosting students for the last. I think it‚Äôs about eight years now. Like, yourself. And I think the interesting thing about school is because it‚Äôs a single sex school, they don‚Äôt have this thing of some schools have a thing like where all computer science is for boys. Yeah. Or the girls will be put off it because there‚Äôs not a good gender balance in the classroom.

Alice: Exactly that. Yeah, that, that is clearly a big problem and Miss Rowland was absolutely amazing. And in general, I think it‚Äôs so good. She was always saying how amazing it is to kind of bring students in the like universities students in the classroom, just because it kind of gives them a better incentive and creates a different dynamic in school. It makes it even more exciting and interesting for the students to find out more about computer science. So, she‚Äôs truly amazing for being able to do this when general teaching,teachers are amazing in general because it‚Äôs so difficult and you‚Äôre a role model in a way that a teacher. I mean a teacher is a role model.

You‚Äôre a role model in the sense that you‚Äôre somebody who‚Äôs worked as a software engineer. So they can see oh that‚Äôs, you know, that that‚Äôs a possible thing to do. Yeah, exactly. It‚Äôs kind of like someplace like maybe go and they might not think that straight away. Yeah. But they might maybe later on they‚Äôll think oh yeah. I remember, I remember doing that school and yeah, it was that it might sometimes it takes a long time for those seeds that you‚Äôve planted to germinate. It might be quite a lot later.

Alice: Yeah. And I know I think I was alright so I did a format, the end to kind of ask the students questions. And one of the question was, if you know anyone that works in technology, I didn‚Äôt even put, you know, something programmable web, it‚Äôs just in general technology. And I think most of them probably around 70% or something like that. Didn‚Äôt know anyone or the ones that didn‚Äôt know

But I feel like given the fact that they didn‚Äôt know anyone that worked in the environment, the fact that they got not only to meet Mr Roland who‚Äôs teaching the subject and I think it‚Äôs so she‚Äôs teaching it really well. So it‚Äôs very important for them to kind of have her as a figure that‚Äôs always been important to just get to know me because it‚Äôs kind of like if they do think about software engineering or about computer science. I think especially in secondary school, your role is much broader than just hey, here‚Äôs some subject knowledge for you.

And that‚Äôs not the goal anyway, you don‚Äôt have that objective to get them all to become computer scientists, the same way as you learn English and maths, you know, just because you need those things in life. Whatever you end up doing, hmm, it‚Äôs important that, you know, this stuff

Alice: exactly. So I was really nice to talk to them about the main topic that everyone liked and enjoyed and the one that connected us the most was TikTok, right? It‚Äôs just talking about TikTok or the time I used to love saying on TikTok and say it‚Äôs for research purposes, but I‚Äôd stay on TikTok. And I remember I was trying to exp them the concept of (recommender system) algorithms, right? What it shows you, when and why?

Alice: I heard about an increase of kids, having Tourette syndrome ticks, just because that obviously some really nice content creators on TikTok that have to write. And they just obviously just share with the world about it, which is really nice. They raise awareness, they have a lot of fans is really create a community around it but because some some people that will perceive, I don‚Äôt know like easily impressionable. But it‚Äôs kind of to show how much impact TikTok and that the TikToks algorithm in general, social media algorithm has on the brain. Because if you get, if you see something every single day, you create yourself this (filter) bubble, which obviously the students didn‚Äôt know about. right they are what 12?

Yes

Alice: They don‚Äôt get to know about social media bubbles but they use social media. So we‚Äôre talking about kind of this, I kind of mentioned a little bit about body image issues just because there were at the age in which was really easy to think that everyone looks like the Instagram influencers or in that situation TikTok influencers. That you like dogs, and not cats that much. So a dog person TikTok is different than cats person TikToks. Right

27.7 Minority report

Okay, well, good luck with that wish you all the best, and so, there‚Äôs a few other things, a few other things left is so one of them is minority report. So, I asked people, if they identify as being a member of a minority group, we‚Äôve talked about a bit about women in computing. So I guess that‚Äôs one minority group that we can talk about. So we, I think our stats are in Manchester out of about 1300 undergraduate students.

Alice: Yeah

About 20% of them, are female. It‚Äôs not ideal. Obviously 50% would be better but we‚Äôre not there yet.

Alice: Yeah.

And so, what‚Äôs your experience being of that and in the workplace as well. So and what can, what can universities and employers do to make campuses and workplaces more welcoming to women?

Alice: Well, I think my experience is quite different than someone that for example would have grown up in the UK and went to uni here, I think we were talking about stats when we did that little women in STEM event in the Kilburn building. We‚Äôre talking about stats in different countries and I think Romania is quite good with stats in terms of women in computing.

So if you take informatics for example yeah, your informatics class at high school

Alice: was mostly girls because I don‚Äôt know.

It was just an anomaly of your school?

Alice: Most of the really top, I don‚Äôt want to call super top but like a couple of the top scores in terms of like the grade you need to enter in high school because we do a little exam. It‚Äôs kind of like GCSE

it‚Äôs like a sixth form school that you go from age 16 to 18?

Alice: No, before 14. So 15 to 18. So you have some kind of entrance exam but exactly basically at the age of 14. Yeah. I don‚Äôt know how I, but some some of the top schools in terms of grade because I can‚Äôt speak in terms of, like, if they have good results or not, I didn‚Äôt look, would be mostly girls so automatically the people that would go into the classes of informatics and Mathematics would be also more mostly girls.

So your fellow students on that. I mean, I guess you‚Äôre still in touch or you know, about some. Yeah. What sort of what sort of things did they go on?

Alice: I do, I do have plenty of female friends that went computer science and also, you know, applying in general like making the decision. They want to go to a computer science university, kind of like nicer when you know that friend. There‚Äôs also like we didn‚Äôt really start talking about the gender imbalance when we were in high school just because we didn‚Äôt have to just because we didn‚Äôt feel like it.

It wasn‚Äôt an issue?

Alice: Obviously, I came here.

Was that not a shock then? So, you‚Äôve gone from an environment where there is no gender imbalance and then all the sudden it‚Äôs switched and you‚Äôre in an environment which is very male-dominated.

Alice: Exactly. It was, it was really, I don‚Äôt think I picked it up initially, I made a couple of friends where everything was fine. I started noticing, I think all female events and computer science and I thought I was like, oh, that‚Äôs interesting, why did they need that? I mean, obviously I knew that there weren‚Äôt that many women in computer science but I was like why would you need more events? And then I started kind of like understanding how I feel like after doing like groupwork and everything and kind of like seeing that there are little microaggressions that people do.

So Carmen (see chapter @ref(carmen)) was talking about this and we didn‚Äôt really explore. Can you explain what a microaggression is? See figure @ref(fig:microagression-fig).

(#fig:microagression-fig)(ref:captionmicroaggression)

(ref:captionmicroaggression) Microaggressions are something that somebody says to you; they can be a way that you‚Äôve been made to feel. They are often subtle behaviours, but their effects are far from subtle. (Hollowood 2022) Creative Commons BY-SA licensed picture of aggressive teeth-bearing behaviour in a domestic dog by Samasjamas on Wikimedia Commons w.wiki/6qJ6

So perhaps give an example?

Alice: Yeah, I don‚Äôt know that this might be wrong. I‚Äôm gonna say that first. But what hands from microaggression, I think what I think is it‚Äôs kind of like when someone does something that they don‚Äôt think is inherently aggressive, or racist, or sexist, or whatever towards a person. But obviously, if you think about the reason why they did it, it is.

It seems innocuous. You might initially think it‚Äôs innocuous and it‚Äôs not until afterwards. You think that was not a minute? Yeah, I was out of order. Yeah, I yeah. Happen again.

I discovered all of these micro aggressions more I feel like my final year just because in my final years when I started hanging out, I feel like in my first two years it would be like me with one or two friends, right? So it would be like us against computer science, I guess, but in my final year I started staying more in Kilburn (building) obviously with my third year project and I think it was also after COVID, we wanted we wanted to be yeah I‚Äôm being a PASS leader that we want to be in Kilburn more just because we‚Äôve been apart for such a long time. I‚Äôve started hanging out more with females and we started talking more about things that would happen and then I would realise some things would be microaggressions while talking to them.

So, can you give an example that you‚Äôre comfortable talking about?

Alice: No, I‚Äôm making myself comfortable talking about it. I feel like it‚Äôs very important to just chat about things like this. I think that most important one would be, I think, mansplaining which is a very delicate topic (see figure @ref(fig:mansplaining-fig)), just because some people genuinely explain in the rude, way to everyone, it‚Äôs not necessarily that they explain. So mansplaining being like a man explaining to someone, I think the word itself is to a female usually or someone that identifies a female.

(#fig:mansplaining-fig)(ref:captionmansplaining)

(ref:captionmansplaining) When a man comments on or explains something to a woman in a condescending, overconfident, inaccurate or oversimplified manner, that‚Äôs mansplaining. Picture by Ralf Schlesener of the ‚Äúmansplaining statue‚Äù in San Antonio, Texas (Tadlock 2015) on Wikimedia Commons w.wiki/6qfC adapted using the Wikipedia app

Alice: Yeah, it‚Äôs kind of like, oh let me explain to you about why your computer does this. And I‚Äôm like, thank you, I wrote the program, I know why. So obviously it‚Äôs quite a fine line, right? Because sometimes you don‚Äôt know what the other person knows, etc. That a lot of grey areas. However, sometimes like clear mansplaining and initially, I just used to kind of ignoring and be, like it‚Äôs fine. Just because I kind of like society kind of made that acceptable for mansplaining to happen and no one really questions it. But while talking to the girls, I‚Äôd be like, oh my god, that WAS mansplaining! I started calling out people on it. It‚Äôs quite funny, actually. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs rude or not, but I just call them out just because I feel like it‚Äôs nice. And then for them to know,

If you were a man doing that, you‚Äôd be called assertive, right? But if you‚Äôre a woman doing that, you might be called something not very nice.

Alice: Yeah, exactly.

Standing your ground. I‚Äôm not gonna let you do that.

Alice: Exactly. So I feel like it was quite useful in the idea that just talking about, it was very important. I also noticed doing PASS and everything and talking to other also doing. That‚Äôs why we started running the women in computer science, little pop-up events, I can call them just because we realised that just sometimes girls just don‚Äôt know. So if you hear a story, you‚Äôll be like, oh, that happened to me. That wasn‚Äôt nice just because by when microaggressions happen, I feel like they also make you feel a bit little but you don‚Äôt understand why, and you think it‚Äôs normal. You think maybe it‚Äôs because of you, you think it‚Äôs your fault they didn‚Äôt know those things before or because you didn‚Äôt seem like you knew this those things before. So yeah, microaggressions definitely happened. What was the question?

So how to make campuses and workplaces better.

Alice: Oh, it did many things happen that work, I feel like it‚Äôs a bit more, I think it was a bit more obvious at work just because obviously in computer science you interact with a lot of people, every day, 20% of them are girls. I feel like the stats were a bit worse at work, but also, because you were, you were supposed to be in the same team all the time, right? You weren‚Äôt also with COVID, you wouldn‚Äôt really interact with anyone else. You would have your little team, the teams group chat and that would be it. So it was just me and one other girl and loads of men basically. And it was fine, it was absolutely fine but it‚Äôs just kind of you wouldn‚Äôt necessarily have space to talk about some things or I feel like it would be more important for workspaces in universities in general to have open conversations about it. I also remember when we were talking because obviously in our group, we would start talking about this as the girls or complain about something and sometimes like one of the boys with us. Oh, I really know that would happen. Like I didn‚Äôt know in any shape or form that that can happen to you just because I don‚Äôt know, we may be overreacted at a joke that they made, which was intended to be a joke, and they wouldn‚Äôt understand why and we started to explain to them what that joke meant to us. And why it‚Äôs so stressful and so touchy. And why we‚Äôre so touchy on the subject and feel like I‚Äôm so sorry. I did know that and it‚Äôs kind of like the problem is that they didn‚Äôt know that.

Right. Yeah. So talking about it

Alice: everyone‚Äôs more aware of what. Exactly some of the issues are, I do feel like we‚Äôre not necessing this place maybe to talk about it. I know we‚Äôre talking with the girls, doing the women in tech event for we‚Äôre kind of like, sharing experiences giving advice and at one point we were talking about, do we want to have almost a lecture when we invite men as well or everyone basically to attend to kind of explain because I feel like if they would know what women or anyone that‚Äôs not man or fits the stereotype of a white man and can be a science has to go through. Maybe they‚Äôll be more it‚Äôll be more easier for them to empathise with everyone else. But then it was kind of like the issue of, Is it your job and duty to use time and resources? Like, obviously, some people like that, right? And I personally like talking about it and talking in PASS and talking to other people, but it‚Äôs not necessarily just because you‚Äôre a woman doesn‚Äôt need You need to talk about an educate, everyone else around you because sometimes you just don‚Äôt have time

It‚Äôs exhausting.

Alice: Sometimes you‚Äôre exhausted. Sometimes why do I need to teach you how terrible it is? Just try to like be a bit more aware, so I feel like it‚Äôs a bit of a double-edged sword in that you want to educate people, but sometimes you just don‚Äôt have time and resources to do it. So yeah. I‚Äôm pretty sure universities would sort it out though because they‚Äôre quite good with things like this.

And I think employers are wising up to these kinds of things.

Alice: Exactly.

They know we have a diversity problem in, for example, in technology companies and they kind of like working towards it. But it takes a long time to make any progress

Alice: and obviously that comes with the idea of more students need more that I‚Äôve, in general a variety. She does need to pick up computer science in schools and then universities and then they get to the employees So I think it‚Äôs quite of a slower. A slow advancement?

Yeah, its takes years, doesn‚Äôt it? Yeah. Things change because of culture. Okay, good. So, is there anything else you want to say more about minorities?

Alice: Oh, I love to talk about it, but I feel like we are getting on for time?

So good. So thank you for those recommendations, we‚Äôll put them on the playlist and we‚Äôll put them on the show notes that go with this.

27.11 Advice to your former self

So, the last thing is I call this time travel. So, if you could travel back in time to meet yourself as a first year, incoming student, what advice would you give yourself? Now it might be advice for yourself, and that might be different from advice you‚Äôd give to other people. So what you‚Äôd advise like how to get the most out of university?

Alice: I think my personal advice realising now this year, how amazing everyone that I was friends with was I would recommend myself to kind of make a bit more. Obviously it‚Äôs quite overwhelming, right? First year you have a lot of people but I feel like I didn‚Äôt try to make as many friends that were international and British in first year just because probably I was a bit scared language barrier. A bit stressful time Romanian. Yeah, I thought I feel like I was trying to stay a bit more Romanians which I think it was very good for me. Especially in the first semester right now. Working very yeah character to come to a different country and then study in a different language that was shocking.

Yeah.

Alice: But I do feel like all my friendships have been so rewarding and they‚Äôre having really sweet and actually my friends in third. Yeah, I would make jokes with them because I knew them in firstly I was just so scared to say hi to them. So it‚Äôs kind of like, well, good friends. Now why didn‚Äôt I become friends with you in first year?

And I think it‚Äôs an important part of, I mean, we touched a little bit on grades, but I see quite a few students, you know, and it‚Äôs good if they want to get good grades, but then they miss out on some of that social stuff. Which is important and I know it‚Äôs not always easy to balance grades and social life, but I think it‚Äôs an important part of why you‚Äôre here is to meet people from all over the world and you know, some of those people you‚Äôll still be in touch with 30 years later.

Alice: So, I think I think is really good and I feel like Kilburn does that amazingly just because obviously it‚Äôs difficult to balance friends and grades but what is even better is to have friends that you exactly that hope you get your grades. So that‚Äôs why I‚Äôve been doing. It‚Äôs been amazing. It‚Äôs been great. Great mix great.

Okay. So I think that‚Äôs everything. So, important advice, to be bold.

Alice: make friends

and make friends and put yourself out there throughout your university career. So thank you, Alice for joining us today and good luck with your new job starting in September. So, enjoy the rest of the summer. Thank you. And yeah, thank you for coming.

Alice: Thank you so much for having it was lovely.

28 Sneha‚Äôs story

Meet Sneha Kandane, shown in see figure @ref(fig:sneha-fig), she graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Computer Science with Industrial Experience in 2022. She completed her placement at matillion.com in Manchester.

(#fig:sneha-fig)(ref:captionsneha)

(ref:captionsneha) Sneha Kandane. Picture reused from linkedin.com/in/sneha-kandane-931346183 with permission, thanks Sneha.

(ref:podcastblurb)

28.1 What‚Äôs your story Sneha?

So, welcome Sneha, thank you for coming on the show. Let‚Äôs start with, tell us a little bit about yourself and where you come from?

Sneha: So my name is Sneha, like you said, I‚Äôve just finished so I‚Äôm so excited. Just graduated (from) my Bachelor of Science (degree) in Computer Science with a year in industry from the University of Manchester. I‚Äôm actually from Manchester, this is my hometown and but originally grew up here.

You grew up in Manchester?

Sneha: since I‚Äôm twenty three years old, right? Well, okay. But I was originally born in India but like my whole life has been in Manchester. A little bit about me.

28.2 Why study Computer Science?

Good. Okay, so the next question is I‚Äôm really interested to find out why people study computing because there‚Äôs lots of routes into it as a subject. So what was it that made you think this is something I‚Äôd like to spend three or four years at university doing?

Sneha: so it wasn‚Äôt something I was always ‚Äúoh this is my calling‚Äù, you know, this is my this is the field of my choice. I was thinking of various things but I am it may not be as exciting, but that whole going through the education process from like GCSE and then to like a level and then, you know, at that point I think I had that good firm like but you know that ground that footwork. So that‚Äôs really helped because, you know, it made that I had that incremental kind of development when it came to the subject and then like obviously I enjoyed don‚Äôt a bit of computing,

You did on a GCSE (General Certificate of Secondary Education) in computing?

Sneha: Yes and A-level as well. Yeah, right. Okay, so I did both That‚Äôs just because my school offered it I thought you know why not but before I didn‚Äôt have any like in primary school and nothing but I think that really helped so because like I enjoyed it and then also like you know I did do well in it. I thought you know this is maybe like you know a good and it has obviously good prospect as a field and like another thing I always say is it has that right balance between the creativity and problem solving and trying to get you to use your brain because I like my creative sides. I‚Äôm very like, you know, artistic I do a lot of artwork and things. And so this was like, you know, kind of an outlet in some sense as well. And that progressive nature of the subject means, like, you know, you start off small and you get bigger and bigger and bigger, and you get feedback as you go through those steps. So I really enjoyed programming, you write a piece of code and then it does something and you kind of see it, you know, quite instantly like, you know, not always but like, quite most of the time usually, see it doing something and that gives you that gratification. So that was probably the reason why

Good. Okay. You studied computer science in your first year and then at the beginning of the second year you decided to do a placement. Was it something you decided before you came or is it something you decided when you got here? You thought actually I‚Äôd like to do a placement?

Sneha: So actually, so what happened was I was on the bachelor‚Äôs, you know, your standard three year bachelor‚Äôs course. And then I came into the interview day and that‚Äôs when they introduced what an industrial placement is I never even knew what that meant and they explained what it was to me and I thought hey that actually sounds really useful. So on my interview day after that, I spoke to one of the people there and I said, like do you think I could change? So they told me to just email someone and that‚Äôs how like I, you know, switched onto it.

Yeah, definitely. So when what was I mean, I guess you, you must have had some unsuccessful interviews.

Okay.

Sneha: So the company ended up working for was a matillion.com. It‚Äôs in Manchester. (see figure @ref(fig:matillion-fig))

So can you tell us about what Matillion does?

Sneha: So Matillion‚Äôs focus is data transformation. (ETL: Extract, transform, load) So for cloud data warehouses, so it helps companies transform their data, especially, to move it to the cloud and it provides that middle software (middleware) that the product basically helps take the data, you know, extract it from wherever their company may have their data transform it allows the company to transform in a way they see fit. And then, you know, we work with AWS (Amazon Web Services) and Google BigQuery and my Microsoft Azure to like, you know, their day to warehouses, is to keep them all the data there. And I also other products help like analyse data and, like, in the cloud and help, you know, people be able to, like,

(#fig:matillion-fig)(ref:captionmatillon)

(ref:captionmatillon) Matillion is a platform that makes data more productive by empowering coders and non-coders alike to move, transform, and orchestrate data pipelines, faster. Screenshot of the matillion website in 2023 from matillion.com

What was your particular role you there (at matillion)?

Sneha: I was going in as a placement software engineer. So, the good thing was, I wasn‚Äôt even treated as a placement software engineer. I was just treated as a normal software engineer, in the sense that my work wasn‚Äôt separate like in, like, oh, you can do this little project on the side. It was very much. You‚Äôre on the product and you‚Äôre gonna impact as much as anyone else. Yeah. That‚Äôs good. To be to be a part of the team. Yeah, not

not sort of somebody who is making cups of tea?

Sneha: Exactly.

So what would you say the main things you learn from your placement?

Sneha: You learn a whole lot of stuff at university, using the main things you‚Äôve got out for your placement work. So like you for like so you have the educational side where that I learnt a lot about you know, software engineering practices because during uni you learn a lot of theory and learn a lot (about) developing your programming skills and everything. But you know in a practical industrial level, you never really see that side until maybe third year. But before that, I never really got that. So actually how the industry works, how a company a software company works that was what was introduced and I thought that was very interesting and, like different that definitely like, you know, it we did the whole software engineering module in year two. It was like kind of applying those principles but it also helped me kind of understand agile practices more which really helped in third year and just how to co-operate with different team members and when you‚Äôre working on such a big like, you know, this is not just a small repo, it‚Äôs huge and you‚Äôre working on a big product, like how that goes, what the process is like, obviously, you can‚Äôt affect something. So, dangerously. So you, there‚Äôs a whole protocol and you kind of learn about these things and, you know, what‚Äôs the most efficient thing for a team. But also on the other side is just like personally I got a lot of communication like, you know, I built that communication a skill and then also just like ownership of the work that I did because I understood, you know, this is gonna impact something bigger than just, maybe like a coursework in like, you know, university. So you have to really put your effort into it and it‚Äôs more than just something for you. It‚Äôs something bigger. So, you know, taking responsibility and also the good thing about the company I work for is that they, you know, encouraged even me who‚Äôs just like a placement, like, and software engineer. It‚Äôs like, actually coming to meetings. Give my say and like that can actually have an impact on the company. So they, I think that‚Äôs okay. And I guess a lot of cloud stuff as well because you‚Äôve done some theory of the cloud stuff, but actually using it using AWS to in using GCP (Google Cloud Platform) and things like that to do to do stuff. Yes. Customers in your experience as well. Oh, for sure. So most enjoyable partner.

Sneha: That was amazing I think. So one thing that kind of was a bit sad for my placement, it was completely remote because of COVID Obviously. Yeah. 28.4 Final year project: coding their future

So you came back to university, so come back from doing a placement back to university doing your final year project. And so can you tell us a little bit about your final year project? But for our listeners. Can you tell us a little bit about what you to feel?

Sneha: Yes, so my final year project was Coding their Future and my supervisor was you! So, the final year project basically looked into the current state of secondary school, education of computer science and the focus I wanted to take with it was identifying potential problems or issues with the current, state of the education potentially, even the curriculum and then finding actual practical solutions for teaching because currently, the uptake of it is very low. So how can we make that, you know, much better. And so the way that was done, was I worked with a school and a class and trialled different teaching methods, how different materials make create a different materials, used hardware and various other resources to enthuse the students to actually enjoy computer science rather than just have to do it because it‚Äôs part of the school curriculum

Yes, did you find going back into school? Because it‚Äôs very different, isn‚Äôt it being at the front of the classroom? As opposed to being in the classroom as a student. So, how was that? How did you find that?

Sneha: it was actually surreal because I actually went back to my high school with my computer science teacher. So, it was really weird that now I‚Äôm working with my teacher rather than as a student. So, teaching the students, I think I was slightly like blessed in a sense, because the class were really nice. They were all willing to learn. They weren‚Äôt super disruptive. Obviously, there were some characters, but, you know, the teacher was there to like, you know, calm down. Do the behaviour control kind of thing. But it was very interesting to see how they responded. And I was actually very surprised to see, like some of the trends, you know, of how they reacted to different things. And, but also because I taught year 9 class, some of them, that‚Äôs when you choose your options, some of them kind of like, knew coming in, they weren‚Äôt gonna pick computer science. So they didn‚Äôt think to try. So that was slightly (a) struggle when you‚Äôre trying to, you know, get them to do stuff but they don‚Äôt want to because they know they aren‚Äôt interested. So that was slightly, you know,

A bit of a battle.

sneha: Yeah.

Ongoing battle. I suppose?

sneha: Yeah

Good. Okay. So what comes next? So you‚Äôre graduating next week?

sneha: Yes. Next in next Thursday

What are you planning to do after?

sneha: I‚Äôm obviously going to have some time off and relax a bit. I‚Äôm still going to work at Matillion but I won‚Äôt be a placement software engineer. So I‚Äôll be a graduate software engineer. But I do want to get further, even further with education.

Okay, so that‚Äôs the degree bit your degree, your life in four years would cover that very quickly. There‚Äôs a few other things to visit here. So they‚Äôre one of them is minority Report. Sneha: So, with in terms of the university the good thing is, is like it‚Äôs very diverse. Sometimes I‚Äôd say, in my year, there were quite a few.

I think, I need to look at the stats but I think it‚Äôs something around about 25% of undergraduate students in computer science are women. So you‚Äôre in a not a tiny minority, but still a minority. So I wonder if there‚Äôs anything that they‚Äôre not just this university but all universities can do to make the subject more welcoming or interesting or more desirable to women.

Sneha: That was part of my final project was to look at how to introduce, how to demystify, those stereotypes of the subject. you know, encourage females to take up the subject to enjoy the subject. Making it look show, maybe the more creative side, you know, catering to things that women tend to know like, yeah, I think there is that like that, you know, you can kind of tell, it‚Äôs 25%, as I mean, if you like, look at like a lecture theatre or like, you‚Äôll be start, you know, like this big, yeah, obvious indication and even personally, even though there were likely in a lots of females I could talk to and stuff, most of my friends were male not because like I couldn‚Äôt make friends with females but because there weren‚Äôt like as many and, you know, sometimes as, you know, like a few more you want to see like especially, you know, your representation kind of you kind of want to feel a bit more comfortable knowing that you‚Äôre not just the only one and also you‚Äôre able to share experiences where because I think that‚Äôs definitely a big thing you know, you as a woman and you as a male like they‚Äôre they will be differences. And Ifeel like I could have had a bit more of a more comfortable feeling if I could have more female to relate to. But I know the, you know, especially in computer science, there are like initiatives to get that kind of going. So, you know, I can‚Äôt say that there‚Äôs nothing going on. I just think, you know, maybe a little bit more work in that sense. In terms of workplace, I can say that they are definitely trying

Everyone‚Äôs trying. Well, most people are trying. Anyway. It‚Äôs a hard problem, isn‚Äôt it?

Sneha: it really is yeah, they try and introduce seminars or they had like a whole weekly meeting talking about, they got like, professional to talk about these things. But like, as much as you know, there is a lot of diversity. I feel like maybe in the engineering department, there‚Äôs less diversity. Once again, predominantly male and actually, even predominantly, , white males and even more with recruitment to my team, the past three people that have come in, have all been white males and so that I know they are aware. They‚Äôre recruitment is a little bit, you know, maybe not as diverse, and they‚Äôre trying to change that. So I do I see that they are trying, but they‚Äôre obviously things, you like kind of see and like, the reason is like, like the reason why I‚Äôd want to get a bit more diverse as a person like, you know, like from a minority group, it‚Äôs just, you know, these kind of things they do impact your experience computer science or at work, at school. So you kind of want to be able to relate to other people in these experiences. So I think that‚Äôs why like a super important to be able to see that. But what, in terms of teaching, a lot of the lecturers I do, they will a lot of female lecturers and even my like, supervisor from first and second was a female. So, like it would like, I think in terms of like staff and teaching that was quite good diversity.

28.7 One film

I think if anyone asks me this is my film, it‚Äôs called 3 idiots, see figure @ref(fig:three-idiots-fig). (Hirani 2009) It‚Äôs a Bollywood film, but it‚Äôs got a lot of global recognition.

(#fig:three-idiots-fig)(ref:captionidiots)

(ref:captionidiots) 3 Idiots is a 2009 Indian Hindi-language coming-of-age comedy-drama film written, edited and directed by Rajkumar Hirani and co-written by Abhijat Joshi, with producer Vidhu Vinod Chopra. (Hirani 2009)

So obviously it‚Äôs in a different language. What sort of is, is it maybe made recently? Or is it? Oh no, it‚Äôs almost like 2000. I mean not old all the 2009? Yeah, 10 years ago, he‚Äôs old. So it‚Äôs the best Like, obviously, because it‚Äôs in a different language, you may think?

Oh no, like, can‚Äôt really relate, but it‚Äôs like generally, it just it crosses culture.

Does it have all the Bollywood dancing and the music?

Sneha It was it It is. The story is of like three guys who go through who get into like one of the best engineering schools in India and it deals with the pressures of like you know having to do well and it deals also with like different societal issues, you know, pressures of yourself, precious of your family, maybe like this is not the field.

You even want to go in or like all of these like very relatable topics that, you know, I feel like students do go through and but it and it deals with like a lot of like deep hard-hitting problems but it does all of that while still also being like the funniest film ever.

So it‚Äôs like it‚Äôs got the comedy, the drama. It‚Äôs got the romance. It‚Äôs got the suspense. Like, it‚Äôs got everything. Like, that‚Äôs why I recommend it strongly. I don‚Äôt even speak Hindi. So like, I have to watch it with sometimes but still I, I don‚Äôt watch films like over and over again.

But I watched this one like five for six times. Crazy actually.

28.8 Advice to your former self

I‚Äôll make a note of that one definitely. So the last thing to finish up then is I call this time travel. So, if you could travel back in time to meet yourself in the first year, what advice would you give yourself or perhaps current or incoming first, second year, students. What advice would you give them to get the most out of their time at university?

Sneha: So I think to two things. So the first one is just putting yourself out there and taking risks because more often than not, it‚Äôs rewarding. Because even if like it‚Äôs not your even if you don‚Äôt get your like intended result, the fact that you‚Äôve done it and you‚Äôve tried is better than not knowing if you didn‚Äôt try so like especially like when I was applying for like placements and stuff completely out of my like, you know what?

Sneha: I know. So I when I did that, you know, obviously after some time, like I did get that reward from it. So just really putting yourself out of your comfort zone. Going to things and I‚Äôd say, because obviously with COVID and stuff. Like, you know, it was a bit more difficult but even like socially just like, you know, trying to put yourself out there as an introvert. That‚Äôs very scary to me. But it‚Äôs more often than not there‚Äôs pay off from it. So that‚Äôs the first piece and then the second one is just hanging in there. You know persevering because to think that my university journey was super smooth sailing is very naive. I remember first year, obviously University of Manchester has really high standards, especially in the computer science department, and that means with such high standards. You kind of doubt yourself, you think maybe this isn‚Äôt for me and that was definitely something I went through. First year, I was even looking at maybe I should apply for a different course. I think the thing that consolidated, yes, this is your field. This is what, you know, you want to do, was my placement. Yeah, actually,

Right

Sneha: After my placement, I knew I actually enjoyed this. I can do for the rest of my life like this. That consolidated it for me. And so even with struggles and coursework and pressure and eventually those things will finish and those things, you know, you will overcome and then not more often than not. They‚Äôre not gonna impact your life. You know. Long-term so like is you just kind of have to push through that bit? Yeah, now I‚Äôm sitting here about to graduate, so it does pay off just pushing through

That‚Äôs good advice. Okay, good. Well, thank you, thank you for joining us today

Sneha so much for having me

we look forward to seeing you at graduation next week.

Sneha: Yeah, so exciting. Okay. Thank you.

29 Carmen‚Äôs story

Meet Carmen Faura Pr√°xedes, shown in see figure @ref(fig:carmen-fig) she graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Software Engineering with Industrial Experience in 2022 when this episode was first recorded. During her degree, Carmen did placements and internships at disney.com and mckinsey.com.

(#fig:carmen-fig)(ref:captioncarmen)

(ref:captioncarmen) Carmen Faura Pr√°xedes. Picture reused from linkedin.com/in/carmen-faura with permission, thanks Carmen.

(ref:podcastblurb)

29.1 What‚Äôs your story Carmen?

So, welcome Carmen thank you for coming on the show. The purpose of this interview is to catch up with you, find out a little bit more about your journey from arriving here, four years ago through to your journey while you‚Äôve been here and what comes next? So what should we start off with? Can you tell us a little bit about yourself and where you come from? As much or as little as you want to say?

Carmen: I‚Äôm Carmen, I‚Äôm originally from Spain, born and raised there and from small southern town Marbella. So, very different to Manchester.

And you went to school in Spain?

Carmen: Yeah, I went to school in Spain. Never moved abroad until I was 18 when I came to University in Manchester.

29.2 Why study Computer Science?

So what made you choose computer science as a subject?

Carmen: So when I was actually applying for degrees, I didn‚Äôt know what I wanted to do and it was December and obviously applications closed in January and I had to start writing my personal statement, to a point where the head (teacher), a schoolmaster called me and it was like coming. Where‚Äôs your personal statement? You need to start applying. And I don‚Äôt know what I want to do. I knew I liked ICT and art and maths and then he was like, so have you thought about double degree in math and physics? I‚Äôm like, no. Physics it‚Äôs not for me. So, then he said, oh, what about software, engineering, computer science, and I was like, what is that? So back home, it‚Äôs not really a thing, it‚Äôs still the idea that technology is what you do in a basement, antisocial. That‚Äôs the stereotype. So then I was like, sure, let‚Äôs just go for it. And then I ended up applying for software engineering and that‚Äôs how I got here.

That‚Äôs good advice. I think one of the interesting things is is a lot of decisions people make about what to study at university comes from family, teachers and peers etc and sometimes those people good advice, sometimes they don‚Äôt give good advice at all!

Carmen: I told one of my family members that I was going to study software engineering and they had a full-on go at me, I feel why would I do that? I‚Äôm gonna have not a pretty life. I‚Äôm gonna be so miserable. I when I came here, realised, that was not gonna be the right thing was gender.

We‚Äôll talk more about this later, was it perceived as, that‚Äôs not subject for women? Or was that, not on the table?

Carmen: I think at that point it was more, it wasn‚Äôt one of the core traditional paths back home, more like architect, doctors, teaching.

Yeah, good. So, can you tell us a bit then about your story. So you arrived here in Manchester and you‚Äôve been studying. So you actually I suppose fast forward to second year. What happened in second year when you you I think you decided to do a placement from the beginning from the get-go. Was it something? You thought your peers persuaded you? It was a good idea?

Definitely the latter. I came into Manchester not knowing what a placement was, but everyone kind of just said, do a placement, do an internship. It‚Äôs great. So, I kind of got pushed into it changed into that degree. So added that onto my degree, and then started looking for a placement. Second year, was tough time managing that and like, dealing with rejections and all, that is a horny thing to go through. It‚Äôs very draining very heartbreaking but it‚Äôs very rewarding at the end

Time-consuming as well? So how long did it take? How many roughly? How many applications did you do?

Carmen: And I was quite lucky that sense. I think I only did about 14 right? Oh with like maybe four of those being emails that sent out to startups because at the beginning, I wanted to go into more startuppy vibes. But then I decided to go through normal job applications, apply to about 10 and obviously you get the bit but the imposter syndrome. When you get all your friends getting applying to the big companies, I didn‚Äôt want to work for a big company back then. So they obviously get the job opposite first and you feel like you‚Äôre not good enough or you‚Äôre not making it but then the offers starts to come in and then it feels a lot nicer.

And I guess did you have many interviews before? The one you got? Did you have many unsuccessful interviews? Because it‚Äôs not like an interview for university, some universities don‚Äôt have interviews at all, so that‚Äôs a whole new experience in a way, isn‚Äôt it?

Carmen: Yes. Absolutely. I remember the first one I did actually was broke company. I didn‚Äôt really want to apply for, so that was good. But even then, that went absolutely shambles. I we got a tour of the headquarters as well, and the factory. The point at which I was mansplained was very big. I walked out thinking, I don‚Äôt care if I get the offer because I‚Äôm not coming here. So it was a big eye-opening time and then after that I was way pickier with the companies I applied for.

29.3 The Walt Disney Company

And you were in one team for the whole 12 months duration?

Carmen: Yes for nine months

And your work I guess you‚Äôre working with a combination of technical and non-technical people in that role in that year?

Carmen: Yes, it was mainly technical. It was maybe like one or two that were non-technical but that‚Äôs about it.

So on the back of that then you‚Äôve got did a summer internship after you‚Äôve done a placement. I guess was getting interviews a little bit easier. Once you have the first thing under your belt

getting that first job is definitely the hardest and I feel like doing the summer internship after really helped get the most out of it because having already know how to get to new code base and just get familiar enough to speed as much faster.

29.4 McKinsey

The summer internship was at McKinsey? What year was this this? When did the pandemic hit 2020? So you‚Äôd started your placement.

Carmen: Yes. So physically, no, I did it fully, right? You‚Äôre right, you started remotely. I did my full placement remote and then I realised. That‚Äôs not something I ever want to do, again, anyone does. And then when I got the office first summer internship, I got the ones. My first in-person job was two weeks in Mexico. I think that was pretty good.

I hear that Mexican Spanish is very different from Spanish Spanish.

Carmen: I couldn‚Äôt understand the menu when I went to order food. I was like, I don‚Äôt know any of these

Someone was telling me the other day, Spanish person telling me that Google Translate when it does translate from English to Spanish, It does English to Latin or Hispanic Spanish rather than European Spanish Spanish. So, Spanish teachers here can always tell when their students are using Google Translate because it comes up with all these weird Latin American sayings and things that you would never say (in Spain).

Carmen: That makes so much sense actually. Yeah, no. It‚Äôs you can really tell the difference. Especially there are a lot more formal than we are probably.

So you did your summer internship in London and then you came back to Manchester to do your final year?

Carmen: Yes.

So, I suppose, one interesting thing is like, how did you find that transition from, so it‚Äôs all about change, isn‚Äôt it? You sort of you started as an undergraduate and that‚Äôs what one change. So, how did you find that transition back into university?

Carmen: Going back to uni was a lot better than when I started Uni, because I felt like, when I started uni, I was a lost puppy. I didn‚Äôt have any software engineering background, I didn‚Äôt know anything about coding. I didn‚Äôt know what Linux was. I was completely lost. Yeah, good. Okay. So, So what else have we got here? Although there‚Äôs less travel these days with consultancies in the, you know, previously you‚Äôd spend you‚Äôd be like a road warrior, being on the road all the time and now, yeah, you still have to do that face-to-face stuff. But here‚Äôs a lot of stuff via teams and zoom and whatnot.

Carmen: Yes. Um, which is also what I was scared about if that would affect anything.
